title: Many religious people often sound like they are in an abusive relationship with their god. They seem to want to excuse the unjust suffering in the world as if itâ€™s somehow the fault of humanity itself.

author: svenjacobs3
text: A few thoughts from a Christian perspective: 1) The Bible never says God is Father to all. We are adopted into sonship when we profess Jesus Christ as Lord ( Ephesians 1:5-15); otherwise, we stand not as children of God, but children of wrath (Ephesians 2:3). This may be abusive, but it's important to underscore that each of our relationships with God varies SIGNIFICANTLY depending on whether we are saved or not (either we are His enemies, or His children); 2) I would maintain that most of the suffering in the world \*is\* the fault of humanity. Generally, every discussion I have with individuals who assert that people are principally good amounts to the fact that we aren't daily killing each other and that sometimes we put some change in the Salvation Army bucket. The bar is so low when it comes to our supposed selflessness and altruism; 3) Every week someone on this subreddit notes that God is too incomprehensible and great to care and love such small and insignificant beings like humans, but it's interesting - as a mental exercise - that the same logic doesn't make the same people conclude that if God is incomprehensibly good and righteous, that He would - by contrast - be mortified moment by moment with how humanity acts. If He is so great, that humanity should be ignored; why is He not so good, that we should be abhorred? Why would even our charity - as slightly impure as it might be - not insult Him, given that in His light no shadow can abound? Why should He be more forgiving than we could ever imagine, and not more enthusiastic about judging every offense than we could ever imagine? What accounts for your stacking the deck more to our benefit, than to our contempt?

author: hielispace
text:
>The Bible never says God is Father to all.

He created us on day number 6 and as such we are his responsibility.

>This may be abusive, but it's important to underscore that each of our relationships with God varies SIGNIFICANTLY depending on whether we are saved or not (either we are His enemies, or His children);

I do like that you admit to the OP being correct, and then go onto literally justify the absuive behavior. It is an interesting mix of self-awareness and self-delusion. This is absuive. "Love me or suffer" is the textbook definition of an absuive relationship.

>God is too incomprehensible and great to care and love such small and insignificant beings like humans

If God exists I doubt he cares about 10^-82nd percent of the universe (by volume).

>that the same logic doesn't make the same people conclude that if God is incomprehensibly good and righteous, that He would - by contrast - be mortified moment by moment with how humanity acts.

How is that the same logic? I don't see the analogy.

>why is He not so good, that we should be abhorred?

Because goodness never results in abhorrence. Techinally speaking goodness never results in any emotion. An action is good if it decreases unnecessary suffering or harm or both, the emotions of people involed are only relavent if they result in the reduction of harm. The fact I find x action ahorrent is a result of emapthy and rage, not morality.

>Why would even our charity - as slightly impure as it might be - not insult Him, given that in His light no shadow can abound?

That's a warped understanding of morality.

>What accounts for your stacking the deck more to our benefit, than to our contempt?

Do you not hear yourself proving the OPs point for him? Or do you not care. Again, this is textbook absuive relationship stuff. But to actually answer your question. An action is moral if it decreases unnecessary suffering or harm or both, and as such a moral God would stack the deck in our favor because it would decreade unnecessary suffering or harm or both. It's not complicated.

text:
